answers.answer: Hi,My liver enzymes came back elevated on Wednesday too, not has high as you but ALT was 42 and AST was 40.  My endo didn't address the issue an it has me worried so I am headed to a GP on Monday.  I too am an avid exerciser and take synthroid and vitamins.  I am not overweight at current time but struggle with my weight too.I am a weekend wine drinker. We are kind of similar in our habits!!I started researching causes of elevated liver enzymes and did find that it can happen with thyroid disease and I did read something about iron causing it as well.  I am currently taking Iron to raise my ferritin.  Are you supplementing with iron?I am starting to wonder if synthroid is hard on the liver since it is one of the places we convert T4 to T3 which makes me wonder why we only replace with T4.  I know T3 has a shorter life in the body but they can make it slow release.  (I'm not bitter at all...just kidding!!)  I would definitely talk to your doctor and maybe run the tests again.  I hope you figure it out.  My endo didn't even bring it up even though it was flagged high...I wanted to hit him when I got the copy of my lab work!!Marianne

question: I am 35, female, on synthroid for 5 years. I constantly exercise, take vitamins and have a strict low cal diet.  I still gain weight.  Synthroid level was tested and ok as of last week.  Liver enzymes recently came back ,alt of 122 and ast of 64. I had a couple of drinks the night before testing.  I am a weekend drinker, 40 pounds overweight with a family history of diabetes, high bp, my grandmother died of ovarian cancer and mother had a massive heart attack at age of 60.  Are the elevated enzymes of serious concern or should they decrease if abstaining from alcohol altogether? I know I need an ultrasound.
title: elevated liver enzymes
